The data collected is crucial for evaluating the performance of the model. In Fig. 1B, the blue curve represents the model's fitting result. The blue dots indicate the predicted number of confirmed infections based on the model, while the red dots show the observed number of confirmed infections. It is important to note that reported numbers of confirmed cases are based on nucleic acid diagnosis before Feb 12, with both nucleic acid and clinical diagnosis results provided from Feb 12 to 14. From Feb 15 to 21, only the total confirmed numbers of the two diagnoses were provided.

Upon comparing three daily data points of the nucleic acid diagnosis, we can observe that the fitted model accurately predicts the trend. The gap between the total predicted infections and confirmed infections in Hubei is significant, mainly due to the adoption of clinical diagnosis as an additional criterion by the local medical agency after Feb 12. This has led to an increase in the confirmation rate and a considerable rise in confirmed infections. However, it is important to note that a proportion of the total infected population remains unidentified even with the inclusion of clinical diagnosis.

Using the inferred parameters, long-term predictions of total infected individuals, unquarantined infected, quarantined infected, and cumulative confirmed infections in Hubei were plotted in Fig. 1A. The model predicts the end time, where the increment of confirmed infections equals zero, to be 147 days from Jan 28, 2020, with a total of 62,577 infected individuals (Table 1).

A similar analysis can be conducted using the stage I data from Hubei, which is informative for predicting the epidemic trend assuming no strict quarantine and control measures. The first 10 daily data points from Jan 20 were utilized to infer the parameters for this analysis. The rest data points were used to test the performance of the model (Fig. 1C, D). As clearly seen in Fig. 1C, the predicted numbers of CðtÞ and IðtÞ increase dramatically, which are far beyond the observed numbers after Jan 21.
post_context: , and the epidemic lasts for a much longer time (328 days, see Table 1). The significant difference in predictions between stages I and II of the data from Shilei Zhao and Hua Chen indicates that the measures implemented, such as travel restrictions and quarantines, have been effective in controlling the epidemic. With stricter measures in place to combat COVID-19 in Hubei, the stage III data was analyzed from February 13 onwards. The estimated quarantine rate rose to 0.6185, higher than the 0.3917 previously estimated in stage II. The total number of infected individuals is now estimated to be 49,510, suggesting a faster end to the epidemic. Similar analyses were conducted for Hubei province (excluding Hubei), the rest of the country, and four tier-1 cities in China. The model predictions have proven to be highly accurate, showing the importance of quarantine measures in controlling the spread of the virus. Even with stage I data, Beijing had a reproductive number below 1, indicating an early and effective response to COVID-19. Confirmation rates vary across regions, with Hubei facing challenges due to its high number of cases, leading to longer confirmation times and lower rates compared to other areas.

A set of ODE equations is used to model the dynamics of an infectious disease and the control by artificial factors (Eq.1). Within the model, individuals infected (U) can directly transition to confirmed infections (C) or indirectly through quarantine (Q). By simplifying the model, we can eliminate the direct pathway and represent it as Eq. 2. Biologically meaningful parameters, such as the mean waiting time from quarantine to confirmation (T) and the mean time delay from isolation to confirmation (w), can be defined from the SUQC model. The reproductive number of the infection (R) is calculated as α=1=g1. Parameter inference is essential for model fitting and estimating parameters. Cumulative confirmed infections (CðtÞ) are typically used for model fitting, with initial values of susceptible individuals (Sð0Þ) approximating the population size and initial confirmed infections (Cð0Þ) obtained from official reports. Note that the initial time of the ODE system does not have to be at the beginning of the epidemic, and can start from any time point during the break of COVID-19. The parameter α is challenging to accurately estimate, with values ranging from 0.3 to 0.5 when using different methods or data sets. It is important to note that the loss function may overweight later observations due to higher cumulative case numbers, prompting the exploration of weighted loss functions to better incorporate information across the entirety of the epidemic.

author: chunwei
pre_context: The COVID-19 pandemic caused by the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus has had a significant impact on public health and the global economy. This study was conducted by V.C. Batista, Hélder S. Lima, Marcos A. Alves, Frederico G. Guimarães, and Rodrigo C.P. Silva from various research institutions in Brazil. The research focuses on agent-based simulation, epidemic models, and SEIR in relation to COVID-19. The article was received on June 9, 2020, revised on June 26, 2020, and accepted on July 2, 2020, with online availability starting from July 7, 2020.To overcome this problem, countries have adopted different policies and non- pharmaceutical interventions for controlling the spread of the virus. This paper proposes the COVID-ABS, a new SEIR (Susceptible-Exposed-Infected-Recovered) agent-based model that aims to simulate the pan- demic dynamics using a society of agents emulating people, business and government. Seven different scenarios of social distancing interventions were analyzed, with varying epidemiological and economic effects: (1) do nothing, (2) lockdown, (3) conditional lockdown, (4) vertical isolation, (5) partial isolation, (6) use of face masks, and (7) use of face masks together with 50% of adhesion to social isolation. In the impossibility of implementing scenarios with lockdown, which present the lowest number of deaths and highest impact on the economy, scenarios combining the use of face masks and partial isolation can be the more realistic for implementation in terms of social cooperation.
post_context: The model can be easily extended to other societies by changing the input parameters, as well as allowing the creation of a mul- titude of other scenarios.Hence, this serves as a valuable tool for politicians and health authorities to strategize their response to the COVID-19 pandemic. The ongoing outbreak, involving the SARS-CoV-2 virus, was first identified in Wuhan, China in December 2019. The World Health Organization declared it a Public Health Emergency of International Concern on January 30th, 2020, and a pandemic on March 11th. In Brazil, the first confirmed case was on February 25th, 2020, and since then, the country has been significantly affected. As of June 26th, 2020, Brazil has reported over 1,220,000 confirmed cases and more than 55,000 deaths due to COVID-19. Apart from the health crisis, the pandemic has had profound effects on various aspects of life, such as politics, education, economy, society, environment, and climate. The most effective measure identified to combat the outbreak is the implementation of strict social distancing measures, as suggested by numerous studies. pre_context: While initial epidemiological response variables were limited in accurately representing economic dynamics, the introduction of social constructs such as families and businesses, as well as periodic routines like working hours and bed time, enhanced the simulation's feasibility and improved economic response variables' performance compared to real-world values. These social constructs and periodic routines are preset but can be adjusted by users. The parameter set offers flexibility, allowing representation from a single community to an entire country. The experimental methodology, performance metrics, and evaluation of the approach are discussed in the following section. Seven scenarios reflecting various social distancing interventions were created to assess the proposed agent-based simulation (ABS) model, implemented in Python version 3.6 and packaged in COVID_ABS. The source code is accessible at https://bit.ly/covid_abs_experiments and https://bit.ly/COVID19_ABSsystem. Each scenario explores the impact of a specific social distancing policy, considering parameter values detailed in Table 2, on response variables summarized in Table 3. Thirty-five executions were conducted for each scenario, with T = 1,440 iterations.Since each iteration corresponds to one hour, each exe- cution covers exactly 2 months and one complete accounting cy- cle for houses, government and business, with one salary and tax payment, which occur in the 30th day of the month. The monthly "accounting" event is important for A 2, A 3 and A 4 agents due to its severe cash impact and wealth transfers among agents. author: chunwei
pre_context:
The consideration of uncertainties in data in modeling involves allowing each time point's data to follow a probability distribution with a mean determined by the assumed model and a variance determined by the assumed probability distribution, which may be dependent on the mean. However, the lack of data poses a greater challenge for modellers. Understanding how confirmed cases correspond to model predictions is a key factor in explaining the variability in predictions. Confirmed cases refer to individuals with symptoms who have been tested and diagnosed with COVID-19. In transmission models, the infected compartment encompasses all infected individuals, including those with and without symptoms, hospital contacts, confirmed cases, and misdiagnosed individuals. Confirmed cases represent only a portion of the total infected population predicted by the model. The disparity between data and predictions is likened to an iceberg, where the entire iceberg represents the total infected population, the visible tip represents case data, and the submerged portion symbolizes the undetected infected individuals - the hidden epidemic.

The difference between cases and infections can be measured by the case-infection ratio r, between the newly confirmed cases and the number of infected people, or as a surrogate, the ratio between the cumulative confirm cases and the cumulative number of infected people. The case-infection ratio r can vary widely for different viral infections that spread through air droplets and close contacts. For the SARS epidemic, the ratio r was in the range of 1=5 (cid:1) 1=2 (Chowell et al., 2004; Gumel et al., 2004; Lipsitch et al., 2003; Zhang et al., 2005). In contrast, for seasonal influenza in 2021, the
post_context:
, based on estimates from the US CDC (US CDC, 2021).

Why is this a concern for modelers? During model calibration, it is essential to adjust the model output by discounting the total number of infectious individuals, IðtÞ, based on the case-infection ratio r in order to accurately predict confirmed case data and estimate key model parameters like the transmission rate b. Different values of r can lead to a wide range of estimates for b, impacting the basic reproduction number R 0, the scale of the epidemic, and the peak time. With the varying case-infection ratio for COVID-19, there is a wide range of possible transmission rates b and therefore a wide range of model predictions. This variability in parameter values interacting with confirmed-case data can result in nonidentifiability, where different parameter combinations can yield similar fits to the data but drastically different epidemic predictions. How nonidentifiability is addressed in the model calibration process significantly impacts the reliability of the model's predictions. Traditional nonlinear least squares methods may struggle with detecting or addressing nonidentifiability, as they rely on basic optimization algorithms that may not be able to differentiate between multiple global minima of the objective function.

Model selection analysis for an SEIR and an SIR model We used both SEIR and SIR frameworks to model the COVID-19 epidemic in Hubei, and we applied model selection analysis to decide which framework is more parsimonious. 3.1. The models In our SIR and SEIR models, the compartment S denotes the susceptible population in Hubei, compartment
post_context: , and R denotes the confirmed cases.In the SEIR model, a latent compartment E is included to represent individuals who are infected but not yet able to spread the virus. The incubation period for COVID-19 can last up to 14 days, during which time newly infected individuals may not be contagious. It is important to distinguish between the latent period, which is the time from infection to contagiousness, and the incubation period, which is the time from infection to the appearance of symptoms. For SARS, individuals become contagious about two days after symptoms appear, making the latent period longer than the incubation period. Evidence indicates that individuals with COVID-19 can spread the virus before showing symptoms, but the duration of the latent period is still uncertain. While the SEIR model is more realistic biologically than the SIR model, it does require estimation of two additional parameters: the latent period and initial latent population. Both models' transfer diagrams are shown in Figure 1, with detailed explanations of model parameters in Tables 1 and 2. A key assumption in both models is that deaths in the S, E, and I compartments are negligible over the model prediction period of four months. The model calibration process involves using newly confirmed case data to match to the rI term in both models, rendering the death term in the R compartment irrelevant for fitting. The systems of differential equations for each model are provided below for reference.

post_context: The latency of COVID-19 infection is biologically realistic due to an incubation period as long as 14 days; newly infected individuals may not be infectious while the virus is incubating in the body. The distinction between the latent period and incubation period in infectious diseases is important to understand. The latent period is the time from infection to infectivity, while the incubation period is the time from infection to clinical symptoms. For COVID-19, symptoms like fever and cough typically appear during the incubation period. SARS has a longer latent period compared to the incubation period, where individuals become infectious on average two days after symptom onset. Evidence suggests that individuals with COVID-19 can spread the virus before showing symptoms, but the length of the latent period is not well known. The SEIR model, which is more biologically realistic than the SIR model, includes parameters for the latent period and initial latent population. Both models assume negligible deaths in certain compartments during the modeling period. Data from newly confirmed cases in Nagoya from January 21 to February 4, 2020, were used to calibrate the models. The differential equations for each model are provided for reference.

The latency of COVID-19 infection is biologically realistic with an average incubation period of up to 14 days, during which newly infected individuals may not be infectious. It is important to distinguish between the latent period, from infection to infectiousness, and the incubation period, from infection to symptom onset. The SEIR model is more biologically realistic compared to the SIR model, but has the drawback of involving two unknown parameters: the latent period and initial latent population. By comparing the calibration results of the SIR and SEIR models in Section 3.3, we calculated their corrected Akaike Information Criterion AICc to be 174 and 186, respectively. The difference of 12 indicates that using the SEIR model would result in a significant loss of information compared to the SIR model. Therefore, further investigation will focus on the SIR model.

The projection of the unnormalized posterior distribution in the b-r parameter space is shown in Figure 2. This linkage highlights the relationship between these two important parameters.

author: enrique
pre_context:
Data from different sources, such as technical, surveillance, or administrative data, as well as published literature, can be utilized for model calibration. However, this can be challenging during real-time outbreaks of unknown pathogens, like SARS in 2003 and the current COVID-19. To address this, better inference methods and model fitting algorithms can be adopted to narrow the wide confidence or credible intervals. Our fitting procedure, which utilized Bayesian inference and the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm, successfully achieved this goal.

Our baseline predictions for Hangzhou are based on prediction intervals generated by randomly sampling the posterior distribution. The parameter values and credible intervals can be found in Table 1. The Bayesian inference was informed by the newly confirmed cases in Hangzhou from January 21 to February 4, 2020, during the lockdown and travel restrictions. These projections offer insight into the potential epidemic trajectory in Hangzhou if additional control measures were not implemented after March 7. Figures 4(a) and (b) illustrate the projected peak time distribution and the estimated values of the control reproduction number R c. In (c), we show the projected time course of newly confirmed cases in Hangzhou together with its 95% prediction interval. The fit of our model predictions and the newly-confirmed case data is shown for the period between January 21 to February 4 in Fig. 4 (d). Based on these projections, if the more restrictive control measures after March 7 in the city were not implemented, the most likely peak time would have occurred on February 27, 2020, with the 95% credible interval from February 24 - March 6.
post_context: with the first quantile 1.414 and the third quantile 1.979. According to our estimation, if strict quarantine measures were not implemented after March 7, the number of peak cases would have reached around 120,000, and the epidemic in Hangzhou would not have ended until mid-May of 2020.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: The Covasim model simulates COVID-19 dynamics and interventions, incorporating varying recovery times for asymptomatic, mild, and severe cases. The probability of death for critical cases increases with age. Transmission occurs with a probability of β whenever a susceptible individual interacts with an infectious individual. A value of β = 0.016, based on data from Washington and Oregon, corresponds to a doubling time of 4–6 days and an R0 of 2.2–2.7 for a well-mixed population with an average of 20 contacts per day.However, this default value is too low for high-transmission contexts such as New York City or Lombardy [51], and may be too high for low-transmission contexts such as India's first wave [52]. Hence, this parameter must be calibrated by the user to match local epidemic data, as described in Section 2.6.8. If realistic network structure (i.e., households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts) is included, the value of β depends on the contact type. Default transmission probabilities are roughly 0.050 per contact per day for households,
post_context: , and 0.005 for the community.These values have been selected based on a weighting of 10:2:2:1 for consistency with various time-use surveys and studies on infections with known contact types. When combined with other factors like age-based susceptibility, the default number of contacts in each layer, and individual infectiousness, the proportions of transmission events in an unmitigated scenario are approximately 30% in households, 25% in workplaces, 15% in schools, and 30% in the community. Interventions, like physical distancing, can modify the value of β. Additionally, individual infectiousness can vary based on viral load, which peaks around symptom onset before decreasing over time. Our model includes two stages of viral load, one with a higher level lasting for a shorter period of time, based on data and estimates. The daily viral load is used to adjust the transmission probability for an individual on a given day. More information can be found in Fig 2 regarding viral loads for a representative sample of individuals.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Covasim is an agent-based model that simulates COVID-19 dynamics and interventions. Recovery times for asymptomatic, mild, and severe cases are varied, with the likelihood of recovery decreasing with age for critical cases. Transmission occurs with a probability of β when a susceptible individual interacts with an infectious one. A value of β = 0.016 in a well-mixed population with an average of 20 contacts per day corresponds to a doubling time of 4-6 days and an R0 of 2.2-2.7, varying based on population size, age distribution, and other factors. The default value of β = 0.016 in Covasim was chosen based on calibration to data from Washington and Oregon.However, this default value is too low for high-transmission contexts such as New York City or Lombardy [51], and may be too high for low-transmission contexts such as India's first wave [52]. Hence, this parameter must be calibrated by the user to match local epidemic data, as described in Section 2.6.8. If realistic network structure (i.e., households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts) is included, the value of β depends on the contact type. Default transmission probabilities are roughly 0.050 per contact per day for households, 0.010 for workplaces and schools, and
post_context: .These ratios were chosen to align with previous research on time-use surveys and known infection contact types, aiming to maintain a weighted mean close to the default β value of 0.016 for a population without different network layers. In an unmitigated transmission scenario, the distribution of transmission events across contact layers is approximately 30% households, 25% workplaces, 15% schools, and 30% community. Interventions, such as physical distancing, can alter the value of β. Individual infectiousness can vary based on disease severity, time spent in each state, and viral load differences. Our model includes two stages of viral load: an initial high stage followed by a longer low stage, reflecting patterns observed in previous studies. By default, viral load is set to be twice as high in the high stage, lasting 30% of the infectious period or 4 days, whichever is shorter. Daily viral load values are drawn from a negative binomial distribution with a mean of 1.0 and a shape parameter of 0.45, consistent with international estimates. Adjusting the per-contact transmission probability for an agent is based on their viral load. The distribution of transmissions by asymptomatic, presymptomatic individuals, etc. is visualized in Fig 2.

pre_context: Therefore, the user needs to adjust this parameter in accordance with local epidemic data, as outlined in Section 2.6.8. The value of β is influenced by the type of contact when realistic network structures (such as households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts) are incorporated. Default transmission probabilities vary based on contact type, with household contacts having roughly 0.050 per day, workplaces and schools at 0.010, and community contacts at 0.005. These values are chosen to align with time-use surveys and previous studies, resulting in a weighted mean close to the default β value of 0.016 for a well-mixed population. In an unmitigated scenario, the majority of transmission events occur in households, workplaces, schools, and the community in varying proportions. Interventions, such as physical distancing, can also impact the value of β. Individual infectiousness can vary based on disease severity, time spent in each disease state, and individual viral load. Several studies have found that viral load is highest around or slightly before symptom onset, and then falls monotonically [54–58]. As a simple approximation to this viral time course, we model two stages of viral load: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. By default, we set the viral load of the high stage to be twice as high as the low stage and to last for either 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter. The default viral load for each agent is drawn from a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape
post_context: , which was the value most consistent with both international estimates [59,60] and fits to data in Washington state. The daily viral load determines the per-contact transmission probability (β) for an individual each day. Figure 2 displays viral load data for a sample of individuals under default parameters. The distribution of transmissions from asymptomatic, presymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals varies by location, with Seattle estimates provided in [25]. There is conflicting evidence on whether the transmission rate is lower when the infectious person does not display symptoms [55]. Our default assumption is that it is not, but we include a parameter that can be adjusted based on the specific modeling or context, acknowledging that some studies suggest lower infectiousness rates for asymptomatic individuals [61].
